data.name: RangeSet
data.description:
Write a RangeSet class (constructor function) that you can add ranges of numbers to, subtract ranges of numbers from, and test numbers against.

> Note: A "range" is an object with two properties:
> - `from` is the lowest number within the range.
> - `to` is the highest number within the range.

> The values may be equal. All "number" values are integers. All `from` and `to` values should be considered inclusive (the range [5, 10] includes the numbers 5 and 10).

# new RangeSet(from, to)
Creates a new object with the methods below.

If provided, adds a range using the `from` and `to` arguments.

For all function calls in this kata, `from` will always be less than or equal to `to`.


## instance.ranges
An array holding any number of range objects, in any order.

## instance.add(from, to)
Adds a new range to the set. If it overlaps or meets existing ranges, this new range should be merged with them.

```javascript
var r = new RangeSet();
r.add(1, 2); r.add(8, 9);
r.ranges == [1, 2] [8, 9] // 1 2 . . . . . 8 9

r.add(4, 6);              // . . . 4 5 6 . . .
// new range overlaps existing; merge
// merged:                   1 2 . 4 5 6 . 8 9
r.ranges == [1, 2] [4, 6] [8, 9]

r.add(7, 7);              // . . . . . . 7 . .
// meets existing range; merge
// merged:                   1 2 . 4 5 6 7 8 9
r.ranges == [1, 2] [4, 9]
```

## instance.subtract(from, to)
Removes the specified range of numbers from the existing ranges.

```javascript
var r = new RangeSet();
r.add(1, 9);
r.ranges == [1, 9]        // 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9

r.subtract(8, 9);         // . . . . . . . 8 9
// numbers removed           1 2 3 4 5 6 7 . .
r.ranges == [1, 7]
```

## instance.test(number)
Returns `true` if the number is within one of the existing ranges. Returns `false` if not.
